Stokes flow

This class solves the Stokes flow problem which is the linearized form of the Navier-Stokes equation

Strong formulation

Momentum equation

\[\nabla p = \nu \nabla^2 \vec{u} + \vec{b}\]

Continuity

\[\nabla \cdot \vec{u} = 0\]

where \(\vec{u}\) and p are the velocity and pressure field respectively with the constants \(\nu\) is the kinematic viscosity. Note that pressure here is the scaled pressure. True pressure \(p_{true} = p/\rho\) where \(\rho\) is the density. \(\vec{b}\) is the external body force

Boundary conditions

Fixed value boundary condition

\[\vec{u} = \vec{u}_D \;\forall \vec{x} \in \Gamma_D\]

(pseudo) Traction boundary condition

\[-p\textbf{n} + \nu(\textbf{n} \cdot \nabla)\vec{u} = \vec{t} \;\;\forall \vec{x} \in \Gamma_N\]

Weak formulation

The weak formulation is stated as follows:

For the velocity trial function

\[\mathcal{U} := \{\vec{U} \in H^1(\Omega) | \vec{u} = \vec{u}_D \;\text{on}\; \Gamma_D\}\]

and the corresponding test function

\[\mathcal{W} := \{\vec{w} \in H^1(\Omega) | \vec{w} = 0 \;\text{on}\; \Gamma_D\}\]

And the pressure space

\[\mathcal{Q} := \mathcal{L}_2(\Omega)\]

for external body force \(\vec{b}\) and surface traction \(\vec{t}\), find \(\vec{u} \in \mathcal{U}\) and \(p \in \mathcal{Q}\) with the corresponding test functions \(\vec{w} \in \mathcal{W}\) and \(q \in \mathcal{Q}\) such that

\[0 = \left(\nabla\vec{w}, \nu\nabla\vec{u}\right)_\Omega - \left( \nabla \cdot \vec{w}, p \right)_\Omega - \left(\vec{w}, \vec{b}\right)_\Omega - \left(q, \nabla \cdot \vec{u}\right)_\Omega + (\vec{w}, \vec{t})_{\Gamma_N} + \sum_{\Omega_e} \int_{\Omega_e} \tau \nabla q \cdot \nabla p d\Omega\]

Stabilization parameters

For linear element, the stabilization is defined according to [1] as

\[\begin{split}\tau = \frac{1}{3} \frac{h^2}{4\nu} \\\end{split}\]

Class definition

Here I am overloading the set_bcs from the MultiPhysics because the pressure boundary conditions has to be handled separately

set_weak_form()

The weak form here is the sum of all of the weak forms from every physics
